channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Kunduz Journal: Tending to the Living and the Dead in a Battle-Torn Afghan City
item.media:description: Although the Taliban are not far from the city, streets of Kunduz, Afghanistan, are bustling again.
item.description: Hardship and resilience are both evident in Kunduz, which the Taliban have taken over twice in a year.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte on Killing Criminal Suspects: ‘I Used to Do It Personally’
item.description: “I was really looking for a confrontation, so I could kill,” President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines told business leaders at a meeting in Manila.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Malaysian Court Rejects Opposition Leader’s Challenge of Sodomy Conviction
item.description: Anwar Ibrahim, the jailed opposition leader, had hoped for a decision that would let him run against the scandal-ridden prime minister in a coming election.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Battle Over Aleppo Is Over, Russia Says, as Evacuation Deal Reached
item.media:description: A member of Syria’s government forces in Aleppo.
item.description: After a four-year battle, the last rebel fighters agreed to turn over their territory. The United Nations reported that scores were killed as pro-government forces moved in.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Amid Rain of Shells, Aleppo’s Civilians Offer ‘Final Scream’
item.media:description: Buses waiting to transport people from a besieged area of Aleppo, Syria, on Wednesday.
item.description: Artillery shelling resumed on eastern neighborhoods, delaying the evacuation of thousands of civilians and medical staff members who had been expecting to leave.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: U.S. Blocks Arms Sale to Saudi Arabia Amid Concerns Over Yemen War
item.media:description: A mural depicting airstrikes in Sanaa, Yemen, in October. The White House press secretary said the administration had “long expressed some very significant concerns about the high rate of civilian casualties” in the Yemeni conflict.
item.description: Deepening a rift with its Gulf allies, the White House blocked the sale by Raytheon of about 16,000 guided munitions kits over worries about civilian casualties.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: French Terrorism Suspects Appeared Anything But
item.media:description: A bus stop in the Meinau neighborhood of Strasbourg, France. The area, along with the city’s Neuhof section, has yielded major terrorism arrests.
item.media:credit: Benjamin Kilb for The New York Times
item.description: France is unsettled by the arrests of four men, suspected of planning terrorist activities, who showed no sign of radicalization.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: The Perfect Weapon: How Russian Cyberpower Invaded the U.S.
item.media:description: A filing cabinet broken into in 1972 as part of the Watergate burglary sits beside a computer server that Russian hackers breached during the 2016 presidential campaign at the Democratic National Committee’s headquarters in Washington.
item.media:credit: Justin T. Gellerson for The New York Times
item.description: A Times investigation reveals missed signals, slow responses and a continuing underestimation of the seriousness of a campaign to disrupt the 2016 presidential election.
item.dc:creator: ERIC LIPTON, DAVID E. SANGER and SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Child Sexual Abuse Scandal Rocks U.K. Soccer
item.media:description: Andrew Woodward became the first professional soccer player in Britain to go public with his claims of sexual abuse.
item.description: Andrew Woodward said he was raped for years by his coach, Barry Bennell. A decision decades later to go public has inspired others to come forward.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Under Rex Tillerson, Exxon Mobil Forged Its Own Path Abroad
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia presented Rex W. Tillerson, Exxon Mobil’s chief executive, with a medal in 2012 in St. Petersburg.
item.description: Mr. Tillerson, nominated by President-elect Donald J. Trump to be secretary of state, has said America’s sources of oil should be “of little consequence to us.”
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD, DIONNE SEARCEY and NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Trump Pulls Out of Brazil Hotel Project Named in Criminal Inquiry
item.media:description: The Trump Hotel Rio de Janeiro. A spokeswoman for Trump Hotels said that the decision to pull out of the project was made because of problems in completing the luxury property.
item.media:credit: Lianne Milton for The New York Times
item.description: The hotel and another Trump venture in the city had been named in a federal investigation over investments by public pension fund managers in commercial projects.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Egypt Church Bombing and Warns of More to Come
item.media:description: The coffins of victims from Sunday’s bombing of St. Mark’s Coptic Orthodox Cathedral after funeral services in Cairo on Monday.
item.description: After an attack in Cairo that killed 25 people on Sunday, the Islamic State vowed to escalate its “war on polytheism,” a reference to Christianity.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH and NOUR YOUSSEF
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: What in the World: For Dissidents, a Phone Hack to Foil Spying Eyes: Cover the Camera
item.media:description: Some potential targets fight back against phone hackers with a simple countermeasure: a sticker or a patch of masking tape over the camera lens.
item.media:credit: Simone Mudde and Olivier van Breugel
item.description: Authoritarian governments can change a trusted device into a surveillance tool, but some potential targets have found a simple way to fight back.
item.dc:creator: JOHN HARNEY

item.title: Crimean Artifacts Should Be Sent to Kiev, Amsterdam Court Rules
item.media:description: The exhibition “Crimea: Gold and Secrets of the Black Sea” at the Allard Pierson Museum in Amsterdam in 2014.
item.description: A panel of judges decided that the works must be sent to a museum in the capital of Ukraine rather than to the museums in Russian-controlled Crimea that lent them.
item.dc:creator: NINA SIEGAL

item.title: In Major Step for Drone Delivery, Amazon Flies Package to Customer in England
item.media:description: Amazon made its first commercial drone delivery on Dec. 7 in Cambridgeshire, England.
item.description: Jeff Bezos announced on Twitter that his company had made its first automated shipment, a two-mile, 13-minute trip to a shopper in Cambridgeshire.
item.dc:creator: NICK WINGFIELD and MARK SCOTT

item.title: Sinosphere: For China’s State Media, Trump Victory Can’t Cure the ‘American Disease’
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump in Wisconsin on Tuesday. Chinese state news outlets have argued that the United States election demonstrated why one-party rule is right for China.
item.description: A stream of articles in Communist Party publications has argued that the election of Donald J. Trump has showed the United States to be dysfunctional and dissolute.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Calçoene Journal: A ‘Stonehenge,’ and a Mystery, Rises in the Amazon
item.media:description: Calçoene pottery at the Amapá State Scientific and Technological Research Institute in Macapá, Brazil.
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.description: The conventional belief is that only small tribes could have inhabited the Amazon jungle, but new discoveries call that into question.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: No Change in U.S. Commitment to Asia-Pacific Under Trump, Admiral Says
item.media:description: Admiral Harris has been an outspoken critic of China’s expansion in the South China Sea, where it has built artificial islands and military installations in the Spratly archipelago, including Fiery Cross Reef, above.
item.description: “You can count on America now and into the future,” Adm. Harry B. Harris Jr., head of the United States Pacific Command, said Wednesday in Sydney, Australia.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Sinosphere: For Taiwan, a Dilemma Over Identity, Economy and China
item.media:description: President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan addressed naval officers in July, about two months after she took office. Some fear Ms. Tsai’s recent phone call with President-elect Donald J. Trump will destabilize United States-China relations, while others see a welcome rethinking of Washington’s ties to Taiwan.
item.media:credit: Office of The President Taiwan, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Syaru Shirley Lin, a political economist, discusses Donald J. Trump’s break with protocol in talking to Taiwan, and Taiwan’s ambivalence toward economic integration with China.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Protests Erupt Across Brazil as Senate Approves Austerity Measure
item.media:description: Demonstrators attacked the iconic headquarters of the Federation of Industries in São Paulo on Tuesday, evoking some of the fierce protests that have rattled the country in recent years.
item.description: Senators voted for a 20-year cap on federal spending, a cornerstone of President Michel Temer’s plan to restore confidence in the country’s ailing economy.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Recreational Marijuana? Yes, but Tightly Regulated, Canadian Panel Suggests
item.media:description: Jodie Emery at Cannabis Culture Lounge in Vancouver, British Columbia, in June. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has promised to legalize the recreational use of marijuana.
item.description: A panel appointed by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau recommended a controlled system to lift marijuana out of the black market without exposing it to full sunlight.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Pageant Silences Beauty Queen, a Critic of China, at U.S. Contest
item.media:description: Anastasia Lin in Toronto last year. The Chinese authorities later blocked her from attending the Miss World pageant in China.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: Anastasia Lin, a Canadian who was barred from the 2015 Miss World competition in China, has been ordered not to speak publicly during this year’s finals in Maryland.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Protests Erupt in Poland Over New Law on Public Gatherings
item.description: The measure is the latest move in a new round of what the right-wing governing party calls necessary reforms to strengthen the executive branch.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN and JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: E. R. Braithwaite, Author of ‘To Sir, With Love,’ Dies at 104
item.media:description: The Guyanese writer E.R. Braithwaite, circa 1960. He wrote “To Sir, With Love,” drawing on his experiences as a teacher in the East End of London.
item.description: A Guyanese writer and diplomat, he recalled teaching in the East End of London in this memoir, which was the basis for a film starring Sidney Poitier.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: 3 ISIS Terrorism Planners Killed in Syria Airstrike, Pentagon Says
item.description: The three men were killed on Dec. 4 in an airstrike in Raqqa, Syria, the Islamic State’s declared capital, a Pentagon spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: U.N. Drops Wonder Woman as an Ambassador
item.media:description: Lynda Carter, who played Wonder Woman on television, spoke at the United Nations headquarters on Oct. 21.
item.description: The campaign drew complaints from people that the superhero was an inappropriate choice to represent girls’ empowerment.
item.dc:creator: ERIN McCANN

item.title: With ‘Trousergate,’ Politics and Pants Collide in Britain
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain outside 10 Downing Street in November.
item.description: After the British prime minister was criticized for wearing $1,250 leather trousers, many emphasized that no man would face such an attack.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Aleksei Navalny, Putin Critic, Says He’ll Run for President of Russia
item.description: However, Mr. Navalny, the most vocal critic of the Kremlin, is facing a court trial that could make him ineligible to participate in the race.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Tunisian Captain in Deadly Migrant Shipwreck Jailed for 18 Years
item.media:description: The Tunisian captain, Ali Malek Mohammed, second from right, and the Syrian first mate, Bikhit Mahmud, right, on an Italian Coast Guard ship in April 2015, after their boat sank off the Italian island of Lampedusa.
item.description: Ali Malek Mohammed was convicted of causing the deaths of about 700 people. His fishing boat collided with a Portuguese freighter off Italy.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Afghanistan Vice President Accused of Torturing Political Rival
item.media:description: Ahmad Ishchi during an interview with The New York Times in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Tuesday. He said he had been tortured by Vice President Abdul Rashid Dostum.
item.description: In an interview, Ahmad Ishchi said Vice President Abdul Rashid Dostum told him, “I can kill you right now, and no one will ask.”
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and FAHIM ABED
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Christians in U.S. Are Less Educated Than Religious Minorities, Report Says
item.media:description: There were 267 million Christians in the United States when the data was collected, but only 36 percent of them had a postsecondary education.
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.description: A Pew Research Center survey of 151 countries found wide gaps in education among major religions, including among Christians and minority faiths in the United States.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Governor of Jakarta Issues Tearful Denial as Blasphemy Trial Opens in Indonesia
item.media:description: A demonstration against Mr. Basuki in Jakarta on Dec. 2 drew more than 200,000 people but remained peaceful, unlike a previous protest.
item.description: Some analysts see the case as an effort to incite ethnic and religious hatred against Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, who is ethnic Chinese and Christian.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Mexico Grapples With a Surge in Violence
item.media:description: A soldier and a police officer at the scene where two people were killed in April in Acapulco, Mexico.
item.description: In the first 10 months of this year, there were 17,063 homicide cases in Mexico, the highest 10-month tally since 2012.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: The Twists and Turns of ‘La Marseillaise’
item.media:description: “La Marseillaise” was played prior to the first period of a New York Rangers game at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 15, 2015, two days after the attacks in Paris at the Bataclan concert hall, a sports stadium and cafes.
item.media:credit: Cal Sport Media, via Associated Press
item.description: Following the deadly attacks in 2015, the French government is seeking to turn the national anthem, often associated with the political right, into a symbol of unity.
item.dc:creator: ALEX MARSHALL

item.title: Only a Rumbling Volcano Could Make North Korea and the West Play Nice
item.media:description: Mount Paektu, on the border between North Korea and China, erupted 1,000 years ago in one of the most violent volcanic explosions in human history.
item.description: Mount Paektu is sacred to the North Korean people. When a swarm of tiny earthquakes were recorded, the reclusive country decided it needed help.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Colombia Needs Help to Make Peace Last
item.media:description: President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia at the 2016 Nobel Peace Prize concert in Oslo on Dec. 11.
item.description: A half-century war has ended. But it will take many societal changes to build real peace. Promised aid from Washington will be crucial.
item.dc:creator: BERNARD ARONSON

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: To Be or Not to Be a Dictator
item.media:description: Yahya Jammeh had his finger inked at a polling station in Banjul, Gambia, this month.
item.description: Yahya Jammeh, the dictator of Gambia, is trying to hold on to his throne after an electoral defeat.
item.dc:creator: STUART A. REID

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: What Comes After Aleppo Falls?
item.media:description: A poster showing President Bashar al-Assad of Syria inside a government military police office in Aleppo this month.
item.description: After years of bloodletting, one almost welcomes an end to the siege of Aleppo. But what comes next may be worse.
item.dc:creator: FAYSAL ITANI

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
